instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CD3115: What is CD3115? This is a common typo,  the person typing CD3115 was most likely referring to CD3215.
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.CHGR_AMON: What is CHGR_AMON? CHGR_AMON provides DC current sense information to the SMC(System management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip). It comes from the battery charging chip that controls the laptop charger, battery charging, and creation of PPBUS_G3H(ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip depending on the logic board part number and model). This is used for sensors. If a DC current sense sensor is reading off in diagnostics, this is a place to start looking. .
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
Macbook 15 Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, stuck 5v. Any idea ? 

UB300 
CB300: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 0.331 
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0v,
Diode Test on LDO Rails:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL>: on CB308: 3.3v, diode-mode: 0,492 only in one USB port
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on CB306: 1.805v, diode-mode: 0,502 only in one USB port
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on CB305: 1.802v, diode-mode: 0,466 only in one USB port
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: na CB304: 1,1v diode-mode: 0,483  only in one USB port

UB400
CB400: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 0.331
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0v
Diode Test on LDO Rails:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL>: on CB408: 3.3v, diode-mode: 0,486  only in one USB port
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on CB406: 1,8v, diode-mode: 0,502  only in one USB port
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on CB405: 1.8v, diode-mode: 0,467  only in one USB port
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: na CB404: 0v, diode-mode: 0,484  only in one USB port

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
<CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR>: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 0.332
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0V
Diode Test on LDO Rails:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR>: 3.383v, diode-mode: 0,486  only in one USB port
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3106</CAPACITOR>: 1.815V, diode-mode: 0,504  only in one USB port
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR>: 1.799v, diode-mode: 0,469  only in one USB port
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3104</CAPACITOR>: 1.118  , diode-mode: 0,486  only in one USB port

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> 
<CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR>: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 0.331
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0V
Diode Test on LDO Rails:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR>: 3.377v, diode-mode: 0,489  only in one USB port
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3206</CAPACITOR>: 1.802v, diode-mode: 0,502  only in one USB port
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3205</CAPACITOR>: 1.798V, diode-mode: 0,469  only in one USB port

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
Did you check for 1V1 LDO at <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and UB400 connecting charger on their port?

USB-C ports switch to 20V if known good battery is connected?
Any history fault available?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
Board isn't necessarily clean but no liquid contact or relevant visible corrosion. 5v with battery. I have replaced some suspect capacitors.
1V1 LDO is present on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> - on a dedicated USBC connector
UB300 and UB400 has no voltage of 1.1v - on a dedicated USBC connector
Now I have
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> -  0.16v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> only 2.8v
<DIODE>D6902</DIODE> pin 1 5v pin 2 0.120v pin 3 4.8v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
There is a problem on UB300/400 area.
Check UB090 solders, traces and surrounding resistors.
Also check all resistors from pages 104/5; you may need to check page 103 too.

"<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> -  0.16v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> only 2.8v"
Where did you measure, isn't the same power rail?

Check all <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>-13 resistors.
Also check <CAPACITOR>C6907</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R6908</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C6907</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R6908</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>-13 are ok
my mistake <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.16 I thought about <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
Can two <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip be damaged ? whether to focus on UB300/400 area.]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message: Did you check what I said about UB090?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message: UB090 and component are ok. I saw that the UB300 was warming up and replaced it. Now I have 1.1v  on all <CHIP>CD3115</CHIP> but still only  5v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message: Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message: Yes, but I still don't <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0.1v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message: Remove F7000/1 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message: I don't understand it but after replacing it, once is 0.1v and sometimes around 0.02v. regardless of the usb-c connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
Replace what?
Need to see if you get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> when F7000/1 fuses are removed.
We know then if the problem is on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> side, or system side...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
Sorry. I misunderstood you and replaced the F7000 / 1.
Without F7000 / 1 it is 0.01v on <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
So you have a problem on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area, or no communication between SMC and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
Post <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage with battery connected; w/ and w/o charger connected.
Test with known good battery, which holds some charge.
Check if board tries to turn on then, triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
I soldered the F7000 / 1.
With battery i have 20v but
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with battery 11.56 v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> without battery 0.05 v
 <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message: Check if tries to start with battery, when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message: nothing happens,  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>. drops to 0 and appears 3.4

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses at same time?
Also check for pulse at <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> not pulse, only 0v.
Still 20v only on battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message: Post basic voltage for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> 1.26v
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDP</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL> 3.4 v
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>,  <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDP</SIGNAL> 0v"
Check for short there.
If short, or low value, remove <CAPACITOR>C7077</CAPACITOR> and check again; if still short, bad <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
If all OK, replace <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> and test the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
I replaced <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> and is <SIGNAL>TBA_VDDP</SIGNAL> 5v but still won't turn on
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> not pulse, only 0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message: Should change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message: I replaced and still the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 stuck 5v
threads.message:
Then SMC doesn't talk with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> at all.

Check output voltages for <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (7 OF 10) block.
Also check <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>.
